Award.AbstractNarration: This award is made as part of the FY 2015 Mathematical Sciences Postdoctoral Research Fellowships Program. Each of the fellowships supports a research and training project at a host institution in the mathematical sciences, including applications to other disciplines, under the mentorship of a sponsoring scientist. The title of the project for this fellowship to Connor Mooney is "Regularity Theory for Degenerate Elliptic and Parabolic Partial Differential Equations." The host institution for the fellowship is University of Texas-Austin and the sponsoring scientist is Dr. Alessio Figalli.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Partial differential equations (PDEs) describe many phenomena in physics and arise naturally in geometry. This project was centered around several problems concerning the regularity (smoothness and qualitative properties) of solutions to some equations that admit singular (non-smooth) solutions, and have roots in applications such as meteorology, optimal transport, and elasticity.

The outcomes of this research include results on: Sobolev regularity and nonlinear behavior of Schauder estimates for the Monge-Ampere equation (which highlight key obstructions to developing an existence theory for the semi-geostrophic system from meteorology), strict convexity of solutions to the Monge-Ampere equation in critical Sobolev spaces, interior C^2 estimates in 2D for a "model" problem related to the complex Monge-Ampere equation from Kahler geometry, minimizers of a functional describing the crumpling of paper, counterexamples to regularity in low dimensions for parabolic systems which underline the limitations of linear theory, and sharp stability results for the Brunn-Minkowski inequality. This research resulted in 7 publications and 1 submitted paper.

Broader impacts of the project included speaking in several conferences per year (some international), organizing seminars and conferences, and writing expository articles. For example, conferences attended include "Elliptic Partial Differential Equations of Second Order: Celebrating 40 years of Gilbarg and Trudinger's Book," in Creswick, Australia in October 2017, and "Calculus of Variations and PDEs" in Firenze-Montecatini, Italy, in June 2017. We co-organized a session of the AIMS conference on Dynamical Systems, Differential Equations and Applications in Taipei, Taiwan in July 2018. The project also involved giving mini-courses about singularities in the calculus of variations in Bari, Italy; about basic elliptic PDE in Creswick, Australia; and about the Monge-Ampere equation in Turin, Italy and at the Oxford PDE CDT. This resulted in two sets of lecture notes that are accepted for publication. Finally, we continued to write and maintain on our personal website other expository notes which may be useful for graduate students and researchers alike in coming years.


Last Modified: 09/07/2019
Modified by: Connor Mooney
POR.POR_COPY_TXT: Partial differential equations (PDEs) describe many phenomena in physics and arise naturally in geometry. This project was centered around several problems concerning the regularity (smoothness and qualitative properties) of solutions to some equations that admit singular (non-smooth) solutions, and have roots in applications such as meteorology, optimal transport, and elasticity. This research resulted in 7 publications and 1 submitted paper. For example, conferences attended include "Elliptic Partial Differential Equations of Second Order: Celebrating 40 years of Gilbarg and Trudinger's Book," in Creswick, Australia in October 2017, and "Calculus of Variations and PDEs" in Firenze-Montecatini, Italy, in June 2017. This resulted in two sets of lecture notes that are accepted for publication. Finally, we continued to write and maintain on our personal website other expository notes which may be useful for graduate students and researchers alike in coming years.
